subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Paul's keyboard proposal (withdrawn)
msgSnippet: I ve just updated the spreadsheet qs_keybd_proposals.csv to include Moira s changes, the switch of #15 and alternate #36 in BPJ2, and changes in QS-Nu. I ve
messageBody:
I've just updated the spreadsheet 'qs_keybd_proposals.csv' to include
Moira's changes, the switch of #15 and alternate #36 in BPJ2, and
changes in QS-Nu. I've added the half letters and removed BPJ1 and
QS-Up, since no one spoke up in support of either of those proposals.

The changes I made in QS-Nu in this round are for the vowels. After
comparing a number of individual words and longer texts written with
each mapping (see next two messages), I found the vowel assignments in
BPJ2 to be the most readable. QS-Nu now uses almost all of those
assignments. Most of the remaining differences between BBJ2 and QS-Nu
are differences of case.

A design goal of QS-Nu is to use lower case for short vowels and upper
case for long vowels.The only assignment that violates this in QS-Nu
now is A for 32. Another goal is to use upper case for the "loop"
vowels 29, 31, 35 and 37. I've kept Q and P for 35 and 37 for visual
similarity, although I admit this is weak. When I was first memorizing
the letters, I made two "vowel circles", with memory aids. If you
write these down by hand, you'll see the circles:

1)
#36 #34
Up On

#28 #30
Ever After

2)
#37 #35
Out of Oil

#29 #31
Aim by Eye

Note that in QS-Nu the vowels in the first circle are all assigned to
lower case Roman letters, while those in the second circle are
assigned to upper case letters. Since I think of these in groups,
visualizing circles to remember them, using case in this manner helps
me remember their assignments.

Ted


On Jan 5, 2008 8:29 AM, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> On 4.1.2008 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> > I find the assignment of B to #37 to be the weakest in BPJ2.
>
> I myself find B = #37 and q = #35 to be equally weak, and
> second only to R = half-#4, and I think I make this clear
> in my document. Clearly some uneasy assignments will be
> necessary, but I've tried to provide memory cues --
> rationalizations if you will -- even for these, which IMHO
> beats totally arbitrary odd-man-out mappings. In other
> words: I know they are weak, but hope they are not totally
> powerless.
>
>
> /BP 8^)>
> --
> Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
> nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
> if grammarians discuss them.
> -Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
>

I've just updated the spreadsheet 'qs_keybd_proposals.csv' to include
Moira's changes, the switch of #15 and alternate #36 in BPJ2, and
changes in QS-Nu. I've added the half letters and removed BPJ1 and
QS-Up, since no one spoke up in support of either of those proposals.

The changes I made in QS-Nu in this round are for the vowels. After
comparing a number of individual words and longer texts written with
each mapping (see next two messages), I found the vowel assignments in
BPJ2 to be the most readable. QS-Nu now uses almost all of those
assignments. Most of the remaining differences between BBJ2 and QS-Nu
are differences of case.

A design goal of QS-Nu is to use lower case for short vowels and upper
case for long vowels.The only assignment that violates this in QS-Nu
now is A for 32. Another goal is to use upper case for the "loop"
vowels 29, 31, 35 and 37. I've kept Q and P for 35 and 37 for visual
similarity, although I admit this is weak. When I was first memorizing
the letters, I made two "vowel circles", with memory aids. If you
write these down by hand, you'll see the circles:

1)
#36    #34
Up     On

#28    #30
Ever   After

2)
#37    #35
Out of Oil

#29    #31
Aim by Eye

Note that in QS-Nu the vowels in the first circle are all assigned to
lower case Roman letters, while those in the second circle are
assigned to upper case letters. Since I think of these in groups,
visualizing circles to remember them, using case in this manner helps
me remember their assignments.

Ted
